OVERVIEW: The Ring series is a member of the clayey, skeletal, mixed family of mollic Eutroboralfs.  Typically, Ring soils have dark grayish brown, cobbly loam surfaces, brown, cobbly sandy clay B2t horizons, and yellowish brown, cobbly sandy clay loam C horizons.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, smectitic, frigid Typic Haplustalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Ring cobbly loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01 &02--1 to 0 inches; decomposed and decomposing forest litter.  (0 to 2 inches thick)
A1--0 to 6 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) cobbly loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; moderate very fine granular structure; soft, friable, slightly sticky; many very fine, fine, and few coarse roots; many fine pores; 10 percent stones, cobbles, and gravel; slightly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (2 to 6 inches thick)
B21t--6 to 14 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) cobbly sandy clay, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak medium and coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, sticky, very plastic; common fine and very fine and few coarse roots; many fine pores; few very fine tubular pores; common moderately thick clay films on faces of peds and rock fragments; 25 percent stones, cobbles, and gravel; slightly acid; clear wavy boundary.  (7 to 10 inches thick)
B22t--14 to 27 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) cobbly sandy clay, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, sticky, very plastic; few fine and coarse roots; few very fine tubular pores; many moderately thick clay films on faces of peds and rock fragments; 50 percent stones, cobbles, and gravel; neutral; gradual wavy boundary.  (10 to 16 inches thick)
B23t--27 to 39 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) cobbly sandy clay, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, sticky, very plastic; few fine and very fine and few coarse roots; few very fine tubular pores; common moderately thick clay films on faces of peds and rock fragments; 65 percent stones, cobbles, and gravel; neutral gradual wavy boundary.  (10 to 14 inches thick)
C--39 to 60 inches; yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) cobbly sandy clay loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) moist; massive; hard, firm, sticky, plastic; few fine, medium and coarse roots; few very fine tubular pores; 50 percent stones, cobbles, and gravel; neutral.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Colfax County, New Mexico; about 12 miles southwest of Vermejo Park Headquarters; 1,750 feet north and 100 feet west of Ring Place Cowcamp Cabin.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The annual soil temperature is about 45 degrees F. and the summer soil temperature is about 60 degrees F.  The solum ranges from 30 to 45 inches thick.  In some pedons there are lenses and pockets of sandstone and shale at a depth of 50 inches.  Rock fragments range from 10 to 40 percent in the A horizon, from 20 to 35 percent of the B21t horizon, from 40 to 65 percent of the B22t and B23t horizons, and 45 to 75 percent in the C horizon.  Stones make up about 45 percent, cobbles about 40 percent, and pebbles about 15 percent.  Some pedons lack an 0 horizon.  The A1 horizon has value of 4 or 5 dry, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3 dry or moist.  It has weak or moderate, fine or very fine granular structure.  The B2t horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 4 or 5 dry and moist, and chroma of 2 through 4 dry and moist.  It is sandy clay or heavy sandy clay loam with 35 to 50 percent clay and 45 to 60 percent sand.  This horizon has weak or moderate, medium or coarse subangular blocky structure.  The C horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 4 through 6 dry and moist.  It is sandy clay loam with 20 to 35 percent clay.  This horizon has weak coarse subangular blocky structure or it is massive.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES AND THEIR DIFFERENTIAE:  These are the Crest and Pinata series.  Crest and Pinata soils have dry value of 6 or more and moist value of 4 or more in the A horizon or in the upper 7 inches, where mixed.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: SETTING:  Ring soils are on gently sloping to strongly sloping outwash terraces.  Slopes range from 0 to 9 percent.  Elevation ranges from 8,000 to 8,500 feet.  The soils formed in fine to coarse textured material weathered from sandstone, shale, and igneous intrusive rocks.  The climate is continental with an annual temperature of about 43 degrees F. and a summer temperature of about 58 degrees F.  The annual precipitation ranges from 16 to 18 inches with about 60 percent falling during the frost free period.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: PRINCIPAL ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Dargol, Vamer, and Brycan soils.  These soils lack a skeletal control section.  Also, Dargol soils have a lithic contact st depths of 20 to 40 inches.  Vamer soils are shallower than 20 inches to bedrock.  Brycan soils have a mollic epipedon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderately slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Native range, wildlife, recreation, limited timber production, and watershed.  The principal plants are ponderosa pine, blue grama, Kentucky bluegrass, mountain muhly, and pine dropseed.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern New Mexico and southern Colorado.  The series is inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Colfax County, New Mexico, 1974.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
